snippet: One company offers an example of what it means to “go dark,” without the need to file financial information with the S.E.C.
abstract: Floyd Norris High & Low Finance column cites former company Equity Inns, acquired by Goldman Sachs in 2007, as prime example of what can happen when a company decides to 'go dark,' move that allows them to withhold key financial information from minority shareholders and regulators; argues that tactic, streamlined by provisions in 2012's so-called JOBS Act, enables dubious behavior that is suspiciously close to insider trading.
lead_paragraph: One company offers an example of what it means to “go dark,” without the need to file financial information with the S.E.C.

headline.print_headline: Going Dark, And Putting Blindfolds On Investors
headline.main: Going Dark, and Putting Blindfolds on Investors
